content:
• Friday, August 16, 2013
  • AFOP

    Alliance Fiber Optic climbs on yesterday's stock split announcement

    • The market pushed Alliance Fiber Optic (AFOP +8.3%) shares up today after the company announced yesterday that it will carry out a 2-for-1 stock split.
    • The split will have no material effect on the company's future economic prospects or market capitalization. Investors were enthused by management's move nonetheless.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:55 PM | 1 Comment
  • CHK

    Carl Icahn ups Chesapeake stake, shares +1.8% AH

    • Chesapeake Energy (NYSE:CHK) +1.8% AH as Carl Icahn raises his stake in the company to 9.98% from 8.98%, according to an SEC filing.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:33 PM | 5 Comments

  • After-hours top gainers / Losers

    • After-hours top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: GNK +6%. OESX +5%. EWT +5%. CYS +5%. WNR +4%.
    • After-hours top losers: RRD -3%. OCN -2%. VSH -2%. MRC -2%. SHLO -2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:31 PM
  • RKUS

    Ruckus rallies; William Blair encouraged by management talks

    • William Blair's Jason Ader, who is reiterating an Outperform, says meetings with Ruckus' management left his firm with "increased confidence" in Ruckus' (RKUS +2.7%) medium/long-term ability to benefit from growing carrier Wi-Fi deployments.
    • Ader thinks carrier Wi-Fi is turning into a two-horse race involving Ruckus and Cisco (Aruba, Alcatel-Lucent, and Ericsson also compete), and that Ruckus is gaining enterprise Wi-Fi share. He also sees adoption of the Hotspot 2.0 standard (enables automatic discovery/login for carrier and public Wi-Fi networks) acting as a 2014 catalyst.
    • Ruckus and rival Aruba (ARUN +0.7%) outperformed yesterday after Cisco (CSCO -0.9%) reported its Y/Y Wi-Fi hardware growth accelerated in the July quarter. Cisco also mentioned on its CC its recently-acquired Meraki enterprise Wi-Fi unit (a major Aruba rival) saw 100%+ Q/Q order growth, and is now on a $250M+/year order run rate.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:23 PM | 2 Comments
  • RENN

    Renren adds to post-earnings losses following Deutsche downgrade

    • Analyst Vivian Hao, who has cut shares to Sell and lowered her PT to $2.40, isn't pleased with Renren's (RENN -3.5%) Q2 revenue miss and Q3 guidance, which the company attributed to online/mobile game delays.
    • She also notes Renren's ad revenue is stagnating thanks to a shortage of inventory (social networking share losses to Sina/Tencent could be a reason for this), that opex continues to jump thanks to investments in the Nuomi group buy/daily deals unit (Baidu is reportedly interested in it), and that PC-related revenue is being hurt by the mobile shift.
    • Nuomi revenue rose 22% Q/Q and 69% Y/Y in Q2, but was still only $6.2M. Active paying users +700K Q/Q to 3.8M.
    • Renren's online ad revenue only rose 2.4% Y/Y to $15.4M, and game revenue only 1.4% to $22.8M. Other Internet value-added service revenue +43.5% to $5.2M (thanks to the Woxiu virtual talent show service).
    • Jefferies cut Renren to Underperform yesterday, while citing concerns about strong online game competition (from Tencent, Qihoo, and Baidu) and slow mobile ad monetization (even though mobile is now 77% of traffic). The firm also notes Nuomi is estimated to have held only 11.6% of the Chinese group buy market in June (Meituan led with 36.5%).
     
     
     
     
    | 4:52 PM

  • The week's ETF movers - Gainers / Losers

    • The week's ETF movers - Gainers: GDXJ +17.65%. PSLV +14.72%. SIVR +13.19%. SLV +13.06%. GDX +12.54%.
      ETF Losers: VNQ -6.59%. IYR -6.45%. BRF -5.15%. XLU -4.09%. IDU -4.02%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM
  • NWSA

    News Corp slips into the close on reports that Rupert Murdoch considered a 'corporate suspect' in hacking investigation

    • News Corp (NWSA -0.8%) dips into the close on reports that Scotland Yard is investigating Rupert Murdoch as a 'corporate suspect' in its hacking and bribery investigation.
    • The investigation could have serious implications for the ability of its parent company News Corp to operate in the United States.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:22 PM
  • SHPG

    Shire spikes in matter of minutes

    • Shares of Irish drugmaker Shire (NASDAQ:SHPG) suddenly jumped 2.6% around 3:30 before settling down a bit into the close.
    • Investors are hypersensitive to rumors surrounding Irish-domiciled drug companies on the heels of the Elan and Warner Chilcott deals.
    • See our previous coverage for more.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM
  • VIAV

    JDS Uniphase, Finisar close higher thanks to Piper

    • Piper's Troy Jensen reiterated Overweight ratings on both JDS Uniphase (JDSU +1.6%) and Finisar (FNSR +2.5%), and argued Cisco's issues shouldn't affect the optical component vendors.
    • Jensen assigns a $26 PT to Finisar, which is based on a valuation of 18x 2014E op. income + cash. He considers this multiple appropriate due to his belief the company can deliver at least 18% annual op. income growth during the next 3-5 years.
    • JDS has been pressured over the last two days thanks to Cisco, soft earnings/guidance, and a $575M convertible debt offering. Finisar sold off yesterday on account of Cisco, but flew higher last week following a positive July quarter revenue pre-announcement.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:11 PM
  • RRGB

    Analysts weigh in on Red Robin following quarterly results

    • Below is a ratings and price target roundup for Red Robin Gourmet Burgers (RRGB +1.1%) following the company's Q2 report and revised comps guidance.
    • B. Riley downgrades the stock to Neutral from Buy (PT $66).
    • KeyBanc reiterates a Buy and raises its price target to $68 from $65 citing "EPS upside potential, accelerating sales and EPS growth, and tight cost controls."
    • Wunderlich reiterates a Buy and a $70 price target, calling the company's comps growth "dramatically" better than peers.
    • Miller Tabak reiterates a Hold and raises its price target to $60, saying "delays in implementing key initiatives will result in higher SG&A expenses ... thereby muting margin expansion in 2014."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:51 PM
  • LPRI

    Lone Pine fails to make interest payment on senior notes

    • Lone Pine Resources (LPR -39.5%) says it elected not to make the ~$10.1M semi-annual interest payment due on Thursday on its outstanding 10.375% senior notes due 2017.
    • LPR says it is focused on addressing its liquidity and talks with noteholders are continuing.
    • A failure to restructure or refinance its debt likely would result in insufficient liquidity to fund its operations, meet its financial obligations and continue as a going concern.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:46 PM | 2 Comments
  • DRWI

    DragonWave tumbles on $80M mixed shelf filing

    • Shares of DragonWave (DRWI -4.2%) tumble after the company files a mixed shelf registration with the SEC. The Canadian wireless backhaul equipment provider has the right to issue up to $80M of any combination of debt securities, common shares, warrants, and subscription receipts over the next 25 months. (form F-10)
    • The company intends to use proceeds to "strengthen our balance sheet, to fund working capital and for general corporate purposes."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:45 PM
  • AEGN

    Aegion wins contract from the St. Louis Sewer District

    • Aegion (AEGN +1.8%) moves up after announcing that its subsidiary, Insituform Technologies USA, has won a $6.7M contract from the Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District.
    • The company previously won two contracts in April valued at approximately $10.4M.
    • The project entails Insituform installing over 34 miles of its cured-in-place pipe in wastewater pipelines ranging from 8-inches in diameter to 60-inches in diameter throughout the city of St. Louis and surrounding county, as part of a $.4.6B capital improvement and replacement plan.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:23 PM

  • Stocks, bonds cut losses after Hilsenrath rumor

    • All it takes is a rumor. Chatter about an imminent Jon Hilsenrath article is enough to have bond prices bouncing stocks shedding near all of the day's losses.
    • The piece was supposed to come at 3 ET, but that moment has passed. Time for a new rumor.
    • S&P 500 (SPY -0.2%), Nasdaq 100 (QQQ +0.1%). The 10-year Treasury yield dips to 2.84%. TLT -0.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:18 PM | 1 Comment
  • GIS

    Jefferies downgrades General Mills

    • "In our view, it creates the risk for ongoing vol. weakness that is no longer adequately reflected by the stock's valuation," Jefferies says of declining advertising and media spending relative to sales at General Mills (GIS -2.2%).
    • Jefferies cuts its FQ1, FY14, and FY15 EPS estimates slightly and downgrades GIS to Underperform from Hold.
    • "Your advertising and media spending as a percentage of sales has been declining for I think three years now," analyst Thilo Wrede noted on GIS' FQ4 conference call in June. (transcript)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:17 PM | 1 Comment
  • NTR

    Potash miners under pressure as Indian buyers demand discounts

    • Indian potash buyers, the second biggest source of potash demand after China, are demanding deep discounts as Russian miner Uralkali, which shook up the sector's cartel system last month, hikes production to full capacity and threatens to send prices plunging.
    • The moves will further pressure shares of global potash miners, who have already lost up to 20% of their stock market value since the breakup of the cartel.
    • Today: POT -2.8%, MOS -3.1%, AGU -1.2%, SQM -1.9%, IPI -5.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:12 PM | 13 Comments
  • MNK

    Cadence Pharmaceuticals slips on USPTO rejection of certain claims on Ofirmev

    • Cadence Pharmaceuticals (CADX -4.6%) slips after the USPTO issued preliminary decision yesterday rejecting certain claims for one of two licensed patents underlying its Ofirmev injection, now part of a legal fight with Exela Pharma.
    • In response, CADX notes that it's very common for the USPTO to reject some or all of the claims of a patent in an initial office action, and this is not a final decision, but just one step in the reexamination process, which can take many years to complete.
    • The company doesn't expect the decision to have an adverse impact on the pending litigation against Exela.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:10 PM
  • RNA

    Prosensa slides on drisapersen data concerns

    • Not surprisingly, shares of Prosensa (RNA -9%) are notably weaker on the session after data from a trial of drisapersen is optically less impressive in terms of dystrophin response than Sarepta's eteplirsen data.
    • Some caution is warranted when interpreting the results however, as comparisons of the GSK/ RNA data to SRPT's results may be "apples to oranges," to use Baird's terminology.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:56 PM
  • PBR

    Petrobras shuts in production at Gulf of Mexico's Cottonwood field

    • Petrobras (PBR -1.6%) becomes the first company to shut in production due to the low-pressure system headed towards the Gulf of Mexico, evacuating workers from its Cottonwood natural gas and condensate field.
    • BP and Marathon Oil (NYSE:MRO) have evacuated non-essential workers from their Gulf facilities but say production has not been affected.
    • Crews remain on board the FPSO on site at PBR's 80K bbl/day Cascade and Chinook fields.
    • Cottonwood, off the Texas coast, produces at a peak of ~70K boe/day.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM
  • NFEC

    NF Energy +88% on no apparent news

    • The short squeeze is on as shares of China-based NF Energy Saving (NFEC +88%) are skyrocketing on no apparent news.
    • NFEC announced its three- and six-month earnings on Wednesday, but the stock saw very little movement until today.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:45 PM
  • CCCR-OLD

    China Commercial Credit plummets after meteoric post-IPO rise

    • After doubling and then some in its first two days of trading, China Commercial Credit (CCCR-OLD -29.4%) takes a dive.
    • Nevertheless, the shares should still close the week with impressive gains — the stock is still up ~54% from its IPO price.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:41 PM
  • PBR

    Petrobras investors unsure if Brazil will allow another fuel price hike

    • Petrobras (PBR -1.6%) shares have settled into a loss after a Brazilian newspaper reported the government may allow the company to raise fuel prices beyond an earlier hike this past spring, prompting a 5% surge in New York, but then the government came out denying such talks.
    • Raymond James analysts say PBR management expressed confidence that another round of fuel price hikes is in the works, but they note government policymakers seem unsure about which way to go ahead of October's presidential election.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:19 PM
  • PFE

    Pain Therapeutics, Durect soar on Remoxy hopes

    • News that Pfizer (PFE -1.6%) is planning a Phase 1 trial of Remoxy sends shares of Pain Therapeutics (PTIE +29.3%) and Durect (DRRX +14.3%) sharply higher in midday trading.
    • Many began to question the drug's fate after PFE indicated in May that a response to the FDA's latest Reomxy CRL likely would not be submitted "before mid-2015."
    • See SA Contributor Red Acre Investments' latest article on Remoxy
     
     
     
     
    | 2:07 PM
  • XEL

    Xcel Energy initiated with a Neutral at UBS

    • Xcel Energy (XEL -1.3%) slips on a tepid initiation from UBS with a Neutral rating and a $30 price target.
    • The firm expects limited appreciation ahead of further details on its growth outlook, which is likely to be presented with an anticipated Analyst Day around December.
    • While the shares could benefit from regulatory approvals of pending wind and gas petitions, the update on its outlook is what's really necessary to drive real share price outperformance.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:02 PM
  • QIHU

    Qihoo soars; company pegs Chinese search share at 20%

    • Down 11% over the prior two days (thanks in part to a general selloff in Chinese tech stocks), Qihoo (QIHU +10%) is flying higher today.
    • A likely trigger: Remarks from president Qi Xiangdong stating Qihoo's So.com search engine (launched a year ago) now has a Chinese query share of 20%. Qi also predicts So.com's query share will top 30% by the end of 2014.
    • Research firm CNZZ gave Qihoo a 15.3% Chinese search share for June, up from 9.6% in Oct. '12. Baidu (BIDU -0.5%) was assigned a 69.4% June share (down from 73% in Oct. '12).
    • Last month, Qihoo announced it's in talks to by Sohu's Sogou search unit (8.8% June share, per CNZZ), but cautioned it hadn't reached "the pricing stage."
    • Shares +132% YTD. Q2 results are due on Aug. 26.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:13 PM
  • BB

    BlackBerry slips; Pac Crest notes purchase commitments

    • BlackBerry (BBRY -3.5%) is giving back a portion of its recent gains. Shares still +15% since Reuters' Aug. 9 report about the company's willingness to go private.
    • Pac Crest's James Faucette (previous) argues today BlackBerry's $5.3B in off-balance-sheet purchase obligations (inc. $4.3B in purchase order commitments) will limit the company's buyout premium.
    • On the other hand, many think BlackBerry's patent portfolio could fetch a hefty sum. MDB Capital's Chris Marlett recently estimated the portfolio is worth $2B-$3B.
    • On Wednesday, Nomura argued a bid above $12-$13/share in unlikely.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:54 PM | 15 Comments

  • Midday top 10 gainers / Losers

    • Midday top 10 gainers: NFEC +69%. NTSC +38%. OTC:MEIL +22%. MTEX +22%. PRGN +20%. PTIE +20%. TOF +19%. DRRX +14%. STP +14%. GPRC +13%.
    • Midday top 10 Losers: FMD -37%. FFHL -27%. MNDL -24%. GTIM -21%. INO -11%. PTEK -10%. INUV -10%. BORN -9%. MCOX -9%. RNA -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM
  • IOC

    InterOil responds to report on Exxon negotiations, shares now -5%

    • InterOil (IOC -5%) bounces a bit from session lows after responding to an earlier report from Papua New Guinea that said Exxon Mobil's (NYSE:XOM) exclusive period for negotiations for a large stake in the Elk-Antelope fields had passed without a deal.
    • IOC says it does not to comment on market rumors or speculation, but negotiations with XOM regarding an agreement to monetize the Elk and Antelope fields are ongoing.
    • Raymond James comes out in defense of the stock, questioning the accuracy of the report.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:38 PM
  • STXS

    Stereotaxis granted approval to transfer to the NASDAQ Capital Market

    • Stereotaxis (STXS +3.2%) says it's been granted approval to transfer its listing to The NASDAQ Capital Market from The NASDAQ Global Market.
    • The company's securities will begin trading on the NASDAQ Capital Market effective at the start of trading on Monday, August 19.
    • The transfer is not expected to have any impact on trading in the 's shares, and the shares will continue to trade on NASDAQ under the symbol STXS.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:32 PM
  • OIBR.C

    Oi falls on negative view in Goldman's Portugal Telecom downgrade

    • Brazilian telco Oi (OIBR -4%) is falling after Goldman aims a spotlight on the company's Q2 results in its downgrade of Oi parent Portugal Telecom (PT-OLD -1.8%).
    • Analyst Tim Boddy: "Much weaker-than-expected 2Q results in Brazil leaves Oi with little room for error to remain within financial covenants and avoid the need for more capital. While Oi’s CEO has a strong track record that gives us confidence for an operational turnaround, and we still view PT’s domestic operations as structurally attractive (albeit with rising NT competitive risk from Vodafone) we now see this outweighed by financial risk."
    • Portugal Telecom is facing significant debt problems of its own.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:19 PM
  • EPZM

    Epizyme receives FDA orphan drug designation for acute leukemia treatment

    • Epizyme (EPZM +3.3%) receives an FDA orphan drug designation for EPZ-5676, its treatment for acute leukemia.
    • EPZ-5676 is a small molecule inhibitor of DOT1L created to treat acute leukemias in which the MLL gene is rearranged due to a chromosomal translocation.
    • Due to the translocation, DOT1L is routed to specific locations in the chromosome where it wouldn't normally be present. As a result, it causes inappropriate methylation at these locations, which results in the increased expression of genes causing leukemia.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:03 PM
  • XSPA

    Vringo soars after court makes royalty ruling

    • The district court handling Vringo's (VRNG +6.4%) IP suit against Google, AOL, Target, IAC, and others has ruled Vringo is "entitled to an award of a post-judgement royalty."
    • The court adds "additional discovery and briefing is necessary to determine the precise nature of the royalty." A royalty rate base of 20.9% has been set.
    • Shares took off earlier this month thanks to a ruling stating Vringo is entitled to supplemental damages and pre-/post-judgment interest related to last November's infringement verdict.
    • Vringo spiked as high as $3.83 in response to today's ruling, but has since pared its gains.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:46 AM | 7 Comments
  • MOV

    Movado moves up on Brean initiation

    • Shares of Movado (MOV +1.8%) are higher after Brean starts the stock at Buy with a $44 price target (19x analyst Eric Beder's FY15 EPS estimate).
    • The company is "poised to buck the weakening trend in watches and to register solid double-digit, bottom-line expansion in FY14 and FY15," Beder says, adding that valuation is more attractive than that of Fossil.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:34 AM
  • AZPN

    Aspen Technology holding on to AH gains; Pacific Crest hikes PT

    • Aspen Technology (AZPN +10.2%) is holding onto the majority of yesterday's AH gains. The stock was up as much as 12% yesterday after Aspen released strong FQ4 results.
    • Pacific Crest raises its PT to $40 from $35 and reiterates a Buy rating. Analyst Brendan Barnicle cited better-than-expected FCF in FQ4 and a slight acceleration of total contract value, license portion of contract value, and annual spending growth from the previous quarter.
    • A caveat: $0.10 of the $0.16 earnings beat in the quarter came from a $9.8M tax benefit arising from simplification of Aspen's Canadian corporate structure.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:18 AM
  • NOK

    Alcatel-Lucent restructures more debt; China Mobile hopes up

    • In the latest in a string of debt refinancing moves that have followed its January deal with Goldman and Credit Suisse, Alcatel-Lucent (ALU +3.2%) has amended two term loan facilities. The interest rate for a $1.75B 2019 facility ($1.74B outstanding) has been lowered to 5.75% from 7.25%, and the rate for a €300M ($400M) 2019 facility (€298M outstanding) has been lowered to 6.25% from 7.5%.
    • Alcatel had €794M ($1.06B) in net debt at the end of Q2, up €436M Q/Q. Total debt amounted to €5.7B, and cash/investments €4.9B.
    • Meanwhile, Evercore is encouraged by the fact China Mobile (CHL - just delivered its Q2 report) still has a 2013 capex budget of $31B (+50% Y/Y). The firm sees Western equipment vendors getting ~30% of procurement orders due this fall. Alcatel, a key supplier for CHL's 4G buildout, should get a meaningful portion of that.
    • CHL has only spent $9.3B on capex thus far in 2013. It plans to spend ~$7B this year on 4G capex, and says it already has 15 phones capable of supporting its TD-LTE 4G network.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:17 AM
  • MACK

    Merrimack continues its slide; sets another new 52-week low

    • Shares in Merrimack Pharmaceuticals (MACK -4.2%) move lower again today to set a new 52-week low once again.
    • Initially, the stock spiked more than 26% higher in the pre-market, possibly helped by a positive Seeking Alpha blog.
    • The SA contributor notes that MM-121, a therapeutic antibody for treating tumors, is the key drug in its portfolio. The company expects three trials involving MM-121 to report in late 2013.
    • If positive, I this could lead to a substantial revaluing of the company, and potentially an acquisition by a larger drug company.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:11 AM
  • MNKD

    Mannkind slips on cautious note out of Summer Street

    • Mannkind (MNKD -7.1%) slips on a negative note out of Summer Street this morning.
    • The firm appears to be suspicious of the results of the drug developer's Phase III AFFINITY 1 trial, after they released results on the injectable insulin and Dreamboat arms but withheld the results on the Medtone C-arm.
    • Releasing data on only two of the three arms of the trial like that is unprecedented.
    • If the results on the Medtone C-arm aren't worthy of presenting and inhalers aren't equivalent, then Summer Street feels there's not enough safety information to approve Dreamboat.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:44 AM | 10 Comments
  • AAXN

    Taser shares extend rally for fourth day

    • Another day, another notable move higher for shares of Taser (TASR +4.8%).
    • The stock is now ~19% above Monday's closing price.
    • The company said this week that its on-officer camera systems have been adopted by law enforcement in Arizona and Dallas/ Forth Worth. (previous)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:37 AM
  • AAL

    Airline stocks show some late-week strength

    • Airline stocks recover some ground lost after the DOJ suit against US Airways and American Airlines rattled the sector.
    • The group is still lower for the week as macroeconomic factors and an indication that the American Airlines bankruptcy plan could be altered have also been factored in.
    • Advancers: US Airways (LCC) +3.2%, Jet Blue (NASDAQ:JBLU) +2.8%, Delta Airlines (NYSE:DAL) +3.1%, United Continental (NASDAQ:UAL) +2.7%, Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV) +1.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:35 AM
  • SU

    Buffett's Suncor stake may be "turning point" for oil sands stocks

    • Warren Buffett’s new 17.7M-share stake in Suncor (SU +1.7%) could spark investor interest in the battered stocks of Canadian oil sands companies, analysts say.
    • Canadian Natural Resources (NYSE:CNQ), Cenovus Energy (NYSE:CVE) and Imperial Oil (NYSEMKT:IMO) - with "scale and access to market and cost discipline" - may get a second look from investors as Wall Street reviews oil and gas plays beyond prolific shale plays in their own backyard.
    • SU produced a record 390K bbl/day in July, and its "new normal" would see output shoot up to 420K, First Energy Capital says.
    • SU is trading at some of the lowest cash flow multiples and, at 80 years, has one of the longest reserve lives in its peer group.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:33 AM | 9 Comments
  • PXLW

    Pixelworks will offer 2.63M shares at $3.50/share in follow-on

    • Pixelworks (PXLW -8.2%) adds to yesterday's AH losses after it announces the details of its follow-on offering. The company will sell 2.63M common shares (equal to 14% of current shares outstanding) at $3.50/share (6.4% discount to today's opening price). The over-allotment option is for 394.5K additional shares.
    • The company intends to use the proceeds for working capital, opex, and capex for its multimedia projector, television, and mobile solutions.
    • Previous: Pixelworks falls AH after announcing follow-on offering
     
     
     
     
    | 10:21 AM

  • Indonesia slides on rupiah concerns

    • Late selling in Jakarta sends Indonesian shares (IDX, EIDO) tumbling 2.5% as the rupiah falls to its lowest level in more than four years. The market is reading Bank Indonesia's decision to refrain from further rate hikes "as a signal that the central bank is prioritizing growth ... [putting] a lot of pressure on the currency," one local analyst tells Bloomberg.
    • Of course pressure on the currency may end up leading to more rate hikes. "Given the concerns over the high level of inflation and the weakness of the rupiah, further rate hikes are likely before the end of the year," Capital Economics' Gareth Leather tells Reuters.
    • Other regional markets: SET (THD) -0.5%, KLCI (EWM) -0.2%, PSEi (EPHE) -0.8%, Straits Times (EWS, EWSS) -0.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:11 AM
  • UACL

    Universal Truckload Services prices offering, shares fall

    • Universal Truckload Services (UACL -5.7%) tumbles after pricing its public offering at $23, a 9.4% discount to Thursday's close. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:44 AM
  • AMAT

    A roundup of tech analyst ratings changes

    • Applied Materials (AMAT +2.1%) has been upgraded to Buy by D.A. Davidson following its FQ3 miss, light FQ4 guidance, and CEO announcement.
    • Morgan Stanley is overhauling its chip stock coverage. Maxim (MXIM -0.4%) has been cut to Equal Weight a day after announcing the Volterra acquisition, and largely getting good reviews for it. Meanwhile, Linear (LLTC +0.6%) and Xilinx (XLNX +1.3%) have been upgraded to Overweight.
    • In addition, MS has started ON Semi (ONNN +0.4%) and Freescale at Underweight, Atmel (ATML +1.7%) and Fairchild (FCS +0.9%) at Overweight, and Microchip (MCHP +0.5%) at Equal Weight.
    • RBC has started another analog chipmaker, Semtech (SMTC +1.6%), at Outperform ahead of its Aug. 21 FQ2 report.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:39 AM
  • CCSC

    Country Style Cooking Restaurant Chain up after earnings

    • Country Style Cooking Restaurant Chain (CCSC +1.9%) rises after Q2 results beat estimates.
    • Revenues rose 16% Y/Y for the period.
    • Comps growth came in at 3.7%.
    • Operating margin fell 218 bps.
    • Q3 outlook: Revenue of $61.9-63.5M representing Y/Y growth of 16.8-19.9%. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:35 AM | 1 Comment
  • P

    Pandora +6.5% premarket on Goldman upgrade to Buy

    • Analyst Heath Terry: "We are encouraged by three quarters of accelerating mobile ad [revenue per 1K hours of listening] and subscription revenue growth, and believe competition concerns are at least adequately understood."
    • He thinks there could be "considerable upside" to consensus thanks to ramping local advertiser spend, sales investment leverage, and integration with radio ad-buying platforms.
    • Terry's bull case scenario imagines Pandora (NYSE:P) reaching $40/share as its total ad RPM rises from an FQ1 level of $28.02 to a radio industry norm of $70, and total ad sales soar to $2.4B.
    • Though up on a Y/Y basis, Pandora's FQ1 mobile ad and total ad RPMs were below FQ3 and FQ4 levels (seasonality was a factor).
    • Terry's upgrade comes ahead of Pandora's Aug. 22 FQ2 report.
    • Previous: Pandora slides after releasing July audience metrics

  • SRPT

    Sarepta gets boost from perceived ambiguity in drisapersen trial results

    • Sarepta Therapeutics (NASDAQ:SRPT) jumps 7% premarket as investors digest new data from a Phase 2 trial of GlaxoSmithKline (NYSE:GSK) and Prosensa's (NASDAQ:RNA) eteplirsen competitor drisapersen.
    • While SRPT and GSK use different definitions for what counts as a dystrophin response (this may be key), it's worth noting that at continuous and intermittent 6mg/kg doses, increases from baseline on at least one of three assays were observed in 72% and 59% of patients for drisapersen, while SRPT claims a 100% effect with eteplirsen.
    • Here's Baird's take: Although drisapersen "may be underdosed ... there appears to be no effort to look at higher doses, despite claims that the proteinuria associated with drisapersen is not clinically relevant."
    • Baird seems to think that any perceived unwillingness on the part of GSK to pursue higher doses may be evidence for claims that drisapersen's safety profile is worse than eteplirsen's.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:19 AM | 1 Comment

  • RBI attempts to boost rupee backfiring

    • Measures by the Reserve Bank of India to try to boost the rupee seem to be backfiring - for now - with the currency hitting a record low of 62.13 to the dollar earlier today. The USD-INR is now +0.7% at 61.87.
    • Meanwhile, shares are -3.4% on fears the RBI is losing credibility.
    • Earlier this week, the RBI said it would cap forex outflows for local firms and residents, steps that economist Radhika Rao says could be perceived as "tantamount to quasi-capital controls." Foreign investors could "rethink plans to invest on fear of controls."
    • Not helping the rupee's cause is the fevered expectation that the Fed will soon start tapering, a prospect that is helping the dollar to strengthen.
    • ETFs - Stocks: INDY, EPI, PIN, INP, INDA, INXX, SCIF, SCIN, INDL, SMIN. Currency: ICN, INR
